description:
Caenorhabditis elegans (C. elegans) is a microscopic, free-living nematode (roundworm) that has become a widely used model organism in biology. It is a small, transparent, and multicellular organism that has been extensively studied for its developmental biology, neurobiology, genetics, and cell biology.

C. elegans has a simple body plan, consisting of only around 1,000 somatic cells, and a well-characterized cell lineage. It has a short life cycle, taking approximately 3 days to develop from an egg to a mature adult at 20Â°C. The adult worm is approximately 1 millimeter in length and has a simple nervous system comprising 302 neurons.

One of the key features that makes C. elegans a valuable model organism is its transparent body, which allows for easy observation and visualization of cellular processes and developmental events using microscopy techniques. Additionally, C. elegans has a completely sequenced genome, making it an excellent system for genetic studies and the exploration of gene function.

C. elegans has been extensively used to study a wide range of biological processes, including cell division, apoptosis (programmed cell death), neurodevelopment, aging, and host-pathogen interactions. The ease of genetic manipulation, short generation time, and well-characterized biology have made C. elegans a powerful model organism for advancing our understanding of fundamental biological principles.
